field.name: Special Consideration for Feeding a Sick Child 0 – < 6 months of Age | Counseling
Breastfeed more frequently during illness, including diarrhoea, to help baby fight sickness, reduce weight loss and recover more quickly
Breastfeeding provides comfort to your sick baby. If your baby refuses to breastfeed, encourage your baby until he or she take the breast again
Give only breastmilk as often as child wants, at least 10 times during the day and night
Only give medicines recommended by your doctor or health care provider
If baby is too weak to suckle, express breastmilk to give the baby. This will help you to keep your milk supply and prevent breast difficulties
After each illness, increase frequency of breastfeeding to help your baby regain health and weight
When you are sick, you can continue to breastfeed your baby. You may need extra food and support during this time
Do NOT give water, sugar water, gripe water, juice, pito, herbal preparations, koko, milk or other liquids or fluids
For HIV mothers who choose not to breastfeed: STOP breastfeeding at 6 months
For babies not breastfed, counsel on other options OR refer
